docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: 🧭 IT Security Architecture Diagram (Mermaid)
docs.text:
Below is a basic security architecture using a Mermaid diagram, rendered automatically in MkDocs Material.

graph TD
    User[User Device]
    Auth[Authentication Provider]
    FW[Firewall]
    Proxy[Secure Proxy]
    App[Internal Application]
    DB[Database]

    User -->|Login| Auth
    Auth -->|Token| FW
    FW --> Proxy
    Proxy --> App
    App --> DB

docs.title: 🔄 Data Flow Diagram (Zero Trust)
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant IdP
    participant Gateway
    participant App

    User->>IdP: Authenticate
    IdP-->>User: Access Token
    User->>Gateway: Request with Token
    Gateway->>App: Forward if token valid
    App-->>Gateway: Response
    Gateway-->>User: Return data

docs.title: 📌 Notes
docs.text: !!! tip Diagrams are just Markdown — no external tooling required. You can document and visualize directly in your docs.

docs.title: 🛡️ Zero Trust Network Architecture Overview
docs.text: This document outlines key components of a Zero Trust network design using Markdown extensions to enhance readability and interactivity.

docs.title: 🔐 Identity & Access Management (IAM)
docs.text:
!!! tip "Use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)" RBAC helps minimize over-permissioning and aligns with the principle of least privilege.

=== "AWS Example"

```yaml
Statement:
  - Effect: Allow
    Action: ec2:DescribeInstances
    Resource: "*"
```

=== "Azure Example"

```json
{
  "RoleDefinitionName": "Reader",
  "Actions": [ "Microsoft.Compute/virtualMachines/read" ]
}
```

docs.title: 🌐 Network Segmentation
docs.text:
# Firewall rule to allow SSH from a bastion host
iptables -A INPUT -s 10.0.0.5 -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT

!!! warning "Avoid opening SSH to the public internet" Exposing port 22 to 0.0.0.0/0 introduces serious risk. Always scope access narrowly.

??? example "Show example NGINX configuration"

```nginx
server {
    listen 443 ssl;
    ssl_certificate /etc/nginx/cert.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/nginx/key.pem;
}
```

docs.title: 🧭 Monitoring & Logging
docs.text:
• Centralized logs
  • Alerts for unauthorized access
  • SIEM integration (e.g., Splunk, Sentinel)
# Example: send logs to remote syslog
logger -n 10.1.1.10 -P 514 "Unauthorized login attempt"

!!! note Logs should be immutable and retained according to compliance requirements.
